title-group.article-title: Popliteal Venous Aneurysm as a Cause of Recurrent Pulmonary Embolism

article-meta.aff: 1First Department of Cardiovascular Medicine, Charles University in Prague, Faculty of Medicine in Hradec Kralove, University Hospital, Sokolska, Hradec Kralove, Czech Republic
2Department of Surgery, Charles University in Prague, Faculty of Medicine in Hradec Kralove, University Hospital, Sokolska, Hradec Kralove, Czech Republic
3Department of Radiology, Charles University in Prague, Faculty of Medicine in Hradec Kralove, University Hospital, Sokolska, Hradec Kralove, Czech Republic

author-notes.corresp: Tomáš Tomko, First Department of Cardiovascular Medicine, Charles University in Prague, Faculty of Medicine in Hradec Kralove, University Hospital, Sokolska 581, 500 05 Hradec Kralove, Czech Republic. Email:tomastomko@hotmail.com

abstract.p: We report 2 cases of recurrent pulmonary embolism (PE) in popliteal venous aneurysm (PVA). Patients were 78-year-old and 72-year-old women. Both were initially seen for acute PE. Saccular and fusiform PVAs were diagnosed in each patient based on duplex ultrasound. However, despite anticoagulation therapy, both patients had PE. At the time of the event, 1 patient was receiving inadequate dose of low-molecular-weight heparin. The other patient was treated with warfarin and had adequate international normalized ratio at the time of re-embolism, and thus, an inferior vena cava filter was inserted. Both patients underwent successful aneurysm resection without any additional thromboembolic events.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Venous aneurysms are a relatively rare abnormality and in most cases they have a benign course. However, popliteal venous aneurysms (PVAs) are an exception as they are a source of venous thromboembolism. They can also present with a life-threatening recurrent pulmonary embolism (PE) in the course of therapeutic levels of anticoagulation. Here, we present 2 cases of recurrent PE in PVA and discuss the pathogenesis, epidemiology, clinical presentation, diagnostic methods, and management of this life-threatening disease.

sec.title: Case 1
sec.p: A 78-year-old woman was admitted due to sudden onset of dyspnea. Her medical history included open stripping of the lower extremity varices, a spontaneous bilateral PE 5 months prior to presentation and a bilocular cystic tumor of the pancreas that was newly revealed. Her family history was without evidence of thromboembolism, and the patient was a nonsmoker. Due to the intended biopsy of the pancreatic tumor, warfarin was stopped 9 days before admission, and low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH) bridging was performed once per day at half therapeutic dose. Two days prior to presentation, biopsy confirmed a benign cystic lesion with malignant potential, and thus an elective laparoscopic distal pancreatectomy was indicated. The patient continued with LMWH therapy and resumed warfarin on the day of admission, when a sudden onset of dyspnea during minimal exercise occurred. Blood gas levels showed slight hyperventilation-induced alkalosis with normoxemia. d-Dimers were positive, and an electrocardiogram (ECG) did not show any pathology. Computed tomography (CT) angiography demonstrated pulmonary re-embolism, confirming the presence of new emboli and the dissolution of previous emboli (Figure 1). Transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) revealed dysfunction and dilatation of the right ventricle with severe pulmonary hypertension. A venous duplex ultrasound of the lower extremities showed a 28 × 20 × 19 mm saccular PVA with thrombus formation (Figure 2). Because the patient did not have a therapeutic dose of LMWH at the moment of re-embolism, an inferior vena cava filter was not indicated. Along with LMWH bridging, warfarin was started, and in 2, respectively, 6-month TTEs, results were normalized. Due to a high risk of re-embolism, after 3 months, the patient first underwent a tangential aneurysmectomy and lateral venorrhaphy of the PVA (Figure 3), and after 6 months, a distal pancreatectomy was successfully performed. During this period, no other thromboembolic events occurred. A 12-month follow-up duplex ultrasound of the popliteal vein was normal, and the patient remains on warfarin therapy.

caption.p: Computed tomography (CT) angiography, arrows show the confirmation of new emboli.
Ultrasound of saccular popliteal venous aneurysm.
Perioperative view, arrows from left to right: distal vena poplitea, vena saphena parva, popliteal venous aneurysm, proximal vena poplitea.

sec.title: Case 2
sec.p: A 72-year-old woman presented with a sudden onset of chest pressure, slowly progressing dyspnea for the last 6 months, and resting dyspnea within the last 3 days. Her family history was positive for venous thromboembolism, and the patient was a former smoker. In the emergency room, blood gas levels showed slight hyperventilation-induced alkalosis with normoxaemia and d-dimers were positive. The CT angiography revealed a bilateral PE. Oncological and basic thrombophilia screening were negative. A venous duplex ultrasound of the lower extremities showed a 46 × 21 mm fusiform PVA with mural thrombus formation. In addition to LMWH bridging, the patient began warfarin treatment. The initial TTE showed dilatation of the right ventricle, with regression following 2 weeks of treatment. The patient was in a good clinical state, with adequate international normalized ratio levels. However, 1 month later, the patient was again admitted due to the sudden onset of chest pressure and progressive dyspnea for 2 days. Due to signs of right ventricle overload on an ECG and again dilatation of right ventricle on the bedside TTE, a diagnosis of recurrent PE was made. A venous duplex ultrasound showed a mural thrombus at the superficial femoral vein, with finding suspicious for a mobile proximal segment, in addition to the known fusiform PVA. Considering the ultrasound findings and effective anticoagulation therapy at the time of re-embolism, a subrenal inferior vena cava filter (Cook) was implanted. The filter was reimplanted 1 week later due to cranial shift. Following 2 weeks of treatment, TTE revealed the normalization of the right ventricle, and the patient continued with LMWH treatment and later with warfarin. After 2 months, a partial resection with plasty of the venous wall was successfully performed. A 12-month follow-up duplex ultrasound of the popliteal vein was normal, and during this period, no other thromboembolic events occurred. The patient remained on warfarin therapy with follow-up at our center.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Venous aneurysms are a relatively rare abnormality, with a prevalence of approximately 8% of the whole-vein malformations. 1 Most are likely congenital and rarely have clinical significance. The rest are caused by trauma, infection, or degenerative changes. It is hypothesized that in congenital vein wall weakness, an acquired impulse leads to aneurismal dilatation. 2 A reduced number of muscle fibers, their replacement with fibrous tissue, 3 and increased expression of matrix metalloproteinases 4 may play a role.

Venous aneurysms have been reported in both the deep and the superficial vein systems. In the neck and upper extremities, they have only esthetic consequences in most cases. In the chest, venous aneurysms represent only incidental findings; however, in the abdomen they may present with bleeding or thromboembolism. The incidence of venous aneurysm is highest in the lower extremities, where they are more frequently asymptomatic. However, PVAs with extremely low incidence are potentially life-threatening disease.

In the literature, just over 150 cases of PVA have been reported. 5 –7 Despite difficulties in estimating PVA prevalence, it appears to be higher than data suggest. Among duplex examinations for various venous symptoms, it was between 0.1% and 0.2%. 8,9 Morphologically, PVAs are mostly saccular (72%-88%), 2,5,10 less commonly fusiform, and defined with diameter at least 3 times (>20 mm) that of the normal popliteal vein. 2,11

Although PVAs are generally asymptomatic, they mainly present with PE (24%-70%). 2,12 This presentation can occur despite adequate anticoagulation because anticoagulation treatment alone has a high rate of failure (43%-71%). 6,10 The presence of thrombus increases the risk of PE from 7% up to 50%. 2 Both sexes are equally affected. 13 Other symptoms include edema, pain, thromboflebitis, postthrombotic changes, intermittent claudication, popliteal masses, and feelings such as tightness or fullness in the popliteal fossa. Common peroneal nerve compression and paradoxical embolization via patent foramen ovale have also been described in few cases. 14
–17 Although rare, the life-threatening presentation of recurrent PE in the course of therapeutic levels of anticoagulation has been reported. Just over 22 such cases have been reported in the world literature to date; however, true prevalence is not well documented. Nevertheless, some authors report a high rate ranging from 33% up to 80%. 2,18,19

Phlebography has long been the predominant method for diagnosis of PVA and remains the most specific and sensitive test for diagnosing PVAs. 20,21 Nevertheless, duplex imaging is considered the best noninvasive diagnostic test. Magnetic resonance imaging and CT represent newer techniques.

Treatment remains controversial. According to prevailing opinion, surgery is recommended for symptomatic patients with thromboembolic events or local symptoms, regardless of the size and shape of the aneurysm, which is supported by the high risk of recurrent PE. In contrast, PE recurrence after surgery has never been reported and surgery accompanied by low local complications (20%-21%) 2,10 with high long-term patency (75%) 10 should therefore be the treatment of choice. In cases of PVA recurrence further surgical repair is required. 2,22,23

For saccular aneurysms, tangential aneurysmectomy is most frequently performed with lateral venorrhaphy. In the rest of the saccular, and in fusiform aneurysms, a resection with end-to-end anastomosis of the popliteal vein or vein interposition grafting is performed. Vein transposition is rarely used. 2,5 When greater saphenectomy is required, it is recommended to perform this as a separate procedure.

There is some consensus in the literature that most patients should receive postoperative anticoagulation for 3 to 6 months. 2,10 It seems reasonable to prescribe anticoagulation for at least the time required to endothelialize the reconstructed area (2-3 months). Long-term anticoagulation should be considered in patients with recurrent thromboembolic events or with the presence of risk factors. We recommend vena cava filter placement before operative repair for patients unsuited for oral anticoagulation or with recurrent PE despite therapeutic levels of anticoagulation.

The treatment for asymptomatic, incidental PVA remains unclear. The little we know is based on a few case reports. On one hand, due to the turbulent venous flow and unpredictable risk of thromboembolism, PVAs should be treated surgically, which is supported by the high recurrence of thromboembolic events despite therapeutic anticoagulation treatment 10,18,19,24,25 and high mortality in patients receiving anticoagulation without subsequent operative repair. 10 On the other hand, in 2 reports of small fusiform and saccular aneurysms observed for a relatively short time without any treatment, no thromboembolic events occurred. The authors therefore concluded that small PVAs with an absence of thrombus appear to have a benign course in patients without a history of thromboembolism. 9,26 They are recommended close surveillance with duplex imaging and considering surgery in the presentation of thromboembolic symptoms. However, these recommendations must be supported by other long-term observations. Likewise, there is no evidence for the prophylactic use of anticoagulation in patients with small asymptomatic fusiform PVAs without the presence of thrombus and in the absence of other thromboembolic risk factors. 2,9,26

With the wider use of duplex imaging, the frequency of incidental PVAs will likely increase. Because PVAs are relatively rare, there remains a void in the treatment experience regarding management options and concerns will continue to arise. The size and shape of the aneurysm, the presence of thrombus, and the high potential for severe PE, even with adequate anticoagulation, should be considered in the management plan. 2
